Comment:
Hi everyone!

Further to my earlier game, I was given the opportunity to co-ordinate a successful mating attack against a kingside castling position.  Funnily enough, Glenda ended up being a mere spectator in this game, but the minor pieces managed to get together and co-ordinate a successful mating attack.  Here is how it happened.  We start off with the Ruy Lopez, an opening I normally play in a double king pawn opening should black's second move be Nc6.
5. 0-0 - I end up tucking Henry away on the kingside.  This is a pretty standard main line Lopez.

6. ..... Bc5 - this is a more unusual line of the Lopez.  It is perfectly playable and hits out at my f2 pawn.  However, this proves not to be a problem.

10. e5 - pawn stab.

11. ..... Nf6 - after the last few moves, disaster strikes for black.  In order to preserve his queen he must move his knight back into my e pawn's attack.  Not only does black lose a piece but the following storm breaks.

19. Qxe1 - suddenly a passed pawn appears on f6 and Glenda2 threatens to make an appearance on f8.  Next move, another new white knight is gonna appear on black's block.
